item.title: Tour de France daily highlights
item.trailText: Throughout Le Tour we will be bringing you a daily video with the best action of the day along with rider profiles, classifications, who is in what jersey and much more
item.standFirst: Throughout Le Tour we will be bringing you a daily video with the best action of the day along with rider profiles, classifications, who is in what jersey and much more. Satge one was a pancake flat 13.8km time trial with some 20 corners through the streets of Utrecht

cards.title: Football / Explore the past, present and future of Chelsea's home
cards.rawTitle: Explore the past, present and future of Chelsea's home

item.title: The history of Chelsea's Stamford Bridge
item.trailText: As plans for a brutalist new home for Chelsea FC are unveiled, described by architect Jacques Herzog as having the feeling of ‘a castle, or a medieval walled village … something you wouldn’t find anywhere else’, we look back at the history of Stamford Bridge
item.standFirst:
As plans for a brutalist new home for Chelsea FC are unveiled, described by architect Jacques Herzog as having the feeling of ‘a castle, or a medieval walled village … something you wouldn’t find anywhere else’, we look back at the history of Stamford Bridge.

Click here to explore the history of Stamford Bridge in our series of Then & Now photography

displayImages.caption: 1 June 1912: A gymnastics display is performed by students at the Polytechnic Harriers meeting at Stamford Bridge. The stadium pre-dates Chelsea Football Club by more than a quarter of a century. It opened on 28 April 1877 as an athletics venue and didn’t become home to the Blues until 1905. Photograph: Topical Press Agency/Hulton/Getty Images
displayImages.altText: 1 June 1912: A gymnastics display is performed by students at the Polytechnic Harriers meeting at Stamford Bridge. The stadium pre-dates Chelsea Football Club by more than a quarter of a century. It opened on 28 April 1877 as an athletics venue and didn’t become home to the Blues until 1905.
displayImages.cleanCaption: 1 June 1912: A gymnastics display is performed by students at the Polytechnic Harriers meeting at Stamford Bridge. The stadium pre-dates Chelsea Football Club by more than a quarter of a century. It opened on 28 April 1877 as an athletics venue and didn’t become home to the Blues until 1905.

displayImages.caption: In 1904, Fulham were offered the first option on the Stamford Bridge ground, their refusal prompting the owner of the freehold, a building contractor named Gus Mears, to found a club of his own, Chelsea. Here, on 6 September 1913, a section of the crowd is photographed before the match between Chelsea and Tottenham Hotspur. Spurs won 3-1 in front of 65,000 spectators. Photograph: Topical Press Agency/Hulton/Getty Images
displayImages.altText: In 1904, Fulham were offered the first option on the Stamford Bridge ground, their refusal prompting the owner of the freehold, a building contractor named Gus Mears, to found a club of his own, Chelsea. Here, on 6 September 1913, a section of the crowd is photographed before the match between Chelsea and Tottenham Hotspur. Spurs won 3-1 in front of 65,000 spectators.
displayImages.cleanCaption: In 1904, Fulham were offered the first option on the Stamford Bridge ground, their refusal prompting the owner of the freehold, a building contractor named Gus Mears, to found a club of his own, Chelsea. Here, on 6 September 1913, a section of the crowd is photographed before the match between Chelsea and Tottenham Hotspur. Spurs won 3-1 in front of 65,000 spectators.

displayImages.caption: September 1918: A bulldog with a collection box strapped to his back on a sports day at Stamford Bridge in aid of disabled people, just before the end of the first world war. Stamford Bridge continued to host other sporting events.  Photograph: A R Coster/Hulton/Getty Images
displayImages.altText: September 1918:  A bulldog with a collection box strapped to his back on a sports day at Stamford Bridge in aid of disabled men, just before the end of the first world war.
displayImages.cleanCaption: September 1918: A bulldog with a collection box strapped to his back on a sports day at Stamford Bridge in aid of disabled people, just before the end of the first world war. Stamford Bridge continued to host other sporting events.

displayImages.caption: 24 April 1920: 50,018 spectators watch the 1920 FA Cup final between Aston Villa and Huddersfield. Stamford Bridge hosted three successive FA Cup finals between 1920 and 1922. Photograph: Alfred Hind Robinson/Getty Images
displayImages.altText: 24 April 1920: 50,018 spectators watch the 1920 F A Cup Final between Aston Villa and Huddersfield. Stamford Bridge hosted three successive FA Cup finals between 1920 and 1922.
displayImages.cleanCaption: 24 April 1920: 50,018 spectators watch the 1920 FA Cup final between Aston Villa and Huddersfield. Stamford Bridge hosted three successive FA Cup finals between 1920 and 1922.

displayImages.caption: 1 August 1935: Chelsea Football Club players report for training at Stamford Bridge, where their first duty is to erect the goal posts. Chelsea continued to be one of the best supported teams throughout the 1930s. On 12 October 1935, a club record 82,905 attended the match against Arsenal at Stamford Bridge. Photograph: A Hudson/Hulton/Getty Images
displayImages.altText: 1st August 1935:  Chelsea Football Club players report for training at Stamford Bridge, where their first duty is to erect the goal posts. Chelsea continued to be one of the best supported teams throughout the 1930s. On 12 October 1935, a club record 82,905 attended the match against Arsenal at Stamford Bridge.
displayImages.cleanCaption: 1 August 1935: Chelsea Football Club players report for training at Stamford Bridge, where their first duty is to erect the goal posts. Chelsea continued to be one of the best supported teams throughout the 1930s. On 12 October 1935, a club record 82,905 attended the match against Arsenal at Stamford Bridge.

displayImages.caption: On 8 September 1939, the FA suspended all matches except those organised by the armed forces. On 15 March 1941, at Stamford Bridge, a team of Allied Forces played the British Army, captained by Stan Cullis and featuring Dennis Compton on the wing. Former player Charles Buchan said that ‘during the greatest war of all times and in the midst of visits from enemy bombers dealing death and destruction, it was possible to gather together a team of sportsmen from conquered countries in Europe, good enough to match their skill against the best England could produce”. Photograph: Popperfoto/Getty Images
displayImages.altText: On 8 September 1939, the FA suspended all matches except those organised by the armed forces. On 15 March 1941, at Stamford Bridge, a team of Allied Forces played the British Army, captained by Stan Cullis and featuring Dennis Compton on the wing. Former player Charles Buchan said that ‘during the greatest war of all times and in the midst of visits from enemy bombers dealing death and destruction, it was possible to gather together a team of sportsmen from conquered countries in Europe, good enough to match their skill against the best England could produce”.
displayImages.cleanCaption: On 8 September 1939, the FA suspended all matches except those organised by the armed forces. On 15 March 1941, at Stamford Bridge, a team of Allied Forces played the British Army, captained by Stan Cullis and featuring Dennis Compton on the wing. Former player Charles Buchan said that ‘during the greatest war of all times and in the midst of visits from enemy bombers dealing death and destruction, it was possible to gather together a team of sportsmen from conquered countries in Europe, good enough to match their skill against the best England could produce”.

displayImages.caption: 13 November 1945: With the second world war just ended, Dynamo Moscow toured Britain. Here, the Russian players walk out on to the pitch at Stamford Bridge, carrying bouquets for their Chelsea opponents. The match was so popular that ticket touts were able to charge up to £5 for tickets that had a face-value of just 10 shillings and the official attendance of 74,496 is considered at least 25,000 short of the true attendance. Photograph: Central Press/Getty Images
displayImages.altText: 13 November 1945: With the second world war just ended, Dynamo Moscow toured Britain. Here, the Russian players walk out onto the pitch at Stamford Bridge, carrying bouquets for their Chelsea opponents. The match was so popular that ticket touts were able to charge up to £5 for tickets that had a face-value of just ten shillings and the official attendance of 74,496 is considered at least 25,000 short of the true attendance.
displayImages.cleanCaption: 13 November 1945: With the second world war just ended, Dynamo Moscow toured Britain. Here, the Russian players walk out on to the pitch at Stamford Bridge, carrying bouquets for their Chelsea opponents. The match was so popular that ticket touts were able to charge up to £5 for tickets that had a face-value of just 10 shillings and the official attendance of 74,496 is considered at least 25,000 short of the true attendance.

displayImages.caption: 20 August 1955: Chelsea display the Football League Championship trophy to fans at Stamford Bridge before the club’s opening match of the season against Bolton. Managed by the former Arsenal player Ted Drake, it was the first time that Chelsea had won the league title. The average attendance at Stamford Bridge was 48,307, the highest in the division.  Photograph: Bert Hardy/Getty Images
displayImages.altText: 20 August 1955: Chelsea display the Football League Championship trophy to fans at Stamford Bridge before the club’s opening match of the season against Bolton. Managed by former Arsenal player Ted Drake, it was the first time that Chelsea had won the league title. The average attendance at Stamford Bridge was 48,307, the highest in the division.
displayImages.cleanCaption: 20 August 1955: Chelsea display the Football League Championship trophy to fans at Stamford Bridge before the club’s opening match of the season against Bolton. Managed by the former Arsenal player Ted Drake, it was the first time that Chelsea had won the league title. The average attendance at Stamford Bridge was 48,307, the highest in the division.

displayImages.caption: Chelsea’s Kings Road became a symbol of the swinging 60s and the mod culture and Steve McQueen, Terence Stamp and Raquel Welsh were regularly seen at Stamford Bridge. Here, in 1965, Jimmy Greaves poses at the door of his Jaguar Mark 2 car outside the stadium. Photograph: Popperfoto/Getty Images
displayImages.altText: Chelsea's Kings Road became a symbol of the swinging sixties and the mod culture and Steve McQueen, Terence Stamp and Raquel Welsh were regularly seen at Stamford Bridge. Here, in 1965, Jimmy Greaves poses at the door of his Jaguar Mark 2 car outside the stadium.
displayImages.cleanCaption: Chelsea’s Kings Road became a symbol of the swinging 60s and the mod culture and Steve McQueen, Terence Stamp and Raquel Welsh were regularly seen at Stamford Bridge. Here, in 1965, Jimmy Greaves poses at the door of his Jaguar Mark 2 car outside the stadium.

displayImages.caption: The construction of the East Stand at Stamford Bridge in the 1970s was described as ‘the most ambitious ever undertaken in Britain.’ However, the costs escalated out of control due to builders’ strikes, a shortage of materials and a global economic crisis and, by 1977, the club was in financial trouble with debts at £4m. Photograph: PA
displayImages.altText: The construction of the East Stand at Stamford Bridge in the 1970s was described as 'the most ambitious ever undertaken in Britain.' However, the costs escalated out of control due to builders' strikes, a shortage of materials and a global economic crisis and, by 1977, the clubs was in financial trouble with debts at £4m.
displayImages.cleanCaption: The construction of the East Stand at Stamford Bridge in the 1970s was described as ‘the most ambitious ever undertaken in Britain.’ However, the costs escalated out of control due to builders’ strikes, a shortage of materials and a global economic crisis and, by 1977, the club was in financial trouble with debts at £4m.

displayImages.caption: Russian billionaire Roman Abramovich bought the club in 2003 for £60m which heralded the most successful era in the history of Chelsea and Stamford Bridge. Photograph: Tom Jenkins for the Guardian
displayImages.altText: Russian billionaire Roman Abramovich bought the club in 2003 for £60m which heralded the most successful era in the history of Chelsea and Stamford Bridge.
displayImages.cleanCaption: Russian billionaire Roman Abramovich bought the club in 2003 for £60m which heralded the most successful era in the history of Chelsea and Stamford Bridge.
displayImages.cleanCredit: Photograph: Tom Jenkins for the Guardian

displayImages.caption: In July 2015 Chelsea revealed their new plans for Stamford Bridge designed by architects Herzog & de Meuron. Commissioned by Roman Abramovich, the project is expected to cost at least £500m and will expand crowd capacity from 42,000 to 60,000, stepping up in a three-tiered stack of terraces. Photograph: Jack Megaw/Focus Images
displayImages.altText: In July 2015 Chelsea revealed their new plans for Stamford Bridge designed by architects Herzog & de Meuron. Commissioned by Roman Abramovich, the project is expected to cost at least £500m and will expand crowd capacity from 42,000 to 60,000, stepping up in a three-tiered stack of terraces.
displayImages.cleanCaption: In July 2015 Chelsea revealed their new plans for Stamford Bridge designed by architects Herzog & de Meuron. Commissioned by Roman Abramovich, the project is expected to cost at least £500m and will expand crowd capacity from 42,000 to 60,000, stepping up in a three-tiered stack of terraces.

displayImages.caption: Architect Jacques Herzog said that the new stadium will have the feeling of “a castle, or a medieval walled village … something you wouldn’t find anywhere else.” He added, “It is beyond beauty or ugliness. It’s about creating something unique. Like Anfield – that is certainly not a nice stadium, but it has this amazing tradition.” Photograph: Jack Megaw/Focus Images
displayImages.altText: Architect Jacques Herzog said that the new stadium will have the feeling of “a castle, or a medieval walled village … something you wouldn’t find anywhere else.” He added, "It is beyond beauty or ugliness. It’s about creating something unique. Like Anfield – that is certainly not a nice stadium, but it has this amazing tradition.”
displayImages.cleanCaption: Architect Jacques Herzog said that the new stadium will have the feeling of “a castle, or a medieval walled village … something you wouldn’t find anywhere else.” He added, “It is beyond beauty or ugliness. It’s about creating something unique. Like Anfield – that is certainly not a nice stadium, but it has this amazing tradition.”

cards.title: Brick-by-brick / Paul Gascoigne's career highlights in all their glory
cards.rawTitle: Paul Gascoigne's career highlights in all their glory

item.title: Paul Gascoigne's career highlights: brick-by-brick
item.trailText: Here are some selected highlights from Gazza's career, painstakingly recreated brick-by-brick
item.standFirst: Many credit Paul Gascoigne with renewing their passion in the England national football team, with one night in Turin being the standout moment. That night, Gazza shed tears for his country, and his country shed tears for him. Here's that moment, and two other highlights from Gazza's career, painstakingly recreated brick-by-brick

cards.title: AFL / Walsh: As mark of respect, game has been abandoned
cards.rawTitle: Walsh: As mark of respect, game has been abandoned

item.title: Phil Walsh: As mark of respect, game abandoned says AFL chief
item.trailText: Gillon McLachlan, chief executive of the AFL, addresses the media following the death of Adelaide Crows coach Phil Walsh, who was 'part of the AFL family for 32 years'
item.standFirst: Gillon McLachlan, chief executive of the AFL, addresses the media following the death of Adelaide Crows coach Phil Walsh, who was 'part of the AFL family for 32 years'. After paying tribute to Walsh, McLachlan announces that this weekend's Crows vs Cats game is abandoned with the points split between the clubs

stillImage.caption: Gillon McLachlan, CEO of the Australian Football League, addresses the media following the death of Adelaide Crows coach Phil Walsh. 3 July 2015 Photograph: AAP Photograph: AAP
stillImage.cleanCaption: Gillon McLachlan, CEO of the Australian Football League, addresses the media following the death of Adelaide Crows coach Phil Walsh. 3 July 2015 Photograph: AAP

cards.title: Tour de France / Team Sky's Froome hoping to avoid injury
cards.rawTitle: Team Sky's Froome hoping to avoid injury

item.title: Tour de France 2015: Team Sky's Chris Froome hoping to avoid injury
item.trailText: Team Sky rider Chris Froome says his crash during last year's Tour de France was 'bad luck' but is confident he will stay injury-free this year
item.standFirst: Team Sky rider Chris Froome says his crash during last year's Tour de France was bad luck but is confident he will stay injury-free this year. Froome crashed out of the 2014 race on stage five after falling from his bike three times. The 2015 Tour begins on Saturday in Utrecht, Netherlands

stillImage.caption: 620x372 trailpic for Tour de France 2015: Team Skys Chris Froome hoping to avoid injury - video Photograph: guardian.co.uk
stillImage.altText: 620x372 trailpic for Tour de France 2015: Team Skys Chris Froome hoping to avoid injury - video

cards.title: Horse racing / Victoria Pendleton thrilled after finishing eighth at Newbury
cards.rawTitle: Victoria Pendleton thrilled after finishing eighth at Newbury

item.title: Victoria Pendleton thrilled after finishing eighth at Newbury
item.trailText: Cycling champion Victoria Pendleton makes her debut as amateur jockey at Newbury on Thursday after only 19 weeks of training
item.standFirst:
Cycling champion Victoria Pendleton makes her debut as amateur jockey at Newbury on Thursday after only 19 weeks of training. Pendleton, with mount Mighty Mambo, finished eighth in a field of 11, and says she is looking forward to be racing more. Pendleton is working toward competing in next year's Cheltenham Festival

• Footage courtesy of Racing UK

cards.title: Wimbledon / A few facts and figures to ponder while queuing for tickets
cards.rawTitle: A few facts and figures to ponder while queuing for tickets

item.title: Wimbledon in numbers
item.trailText: Here are a few facts and figures to ponder while you're queuing for tickets at Wimbledon
item.standFirst:
Here are a few facts and figures to ponder while you're queuing for tickets at Wimbledon. How short do they cut the grass at Wimbledon? How accurate is Hawkeye's tracking technology? How many umbrellas are sold at Wimbledon? How much colour each player is allowed to wear?
Find out the answers to all these questions and more
